metadata.case_name: Collector of Customs, Calcutta v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: The respondent had imported 2,000 drums of mineral oil.
The appellant, the Collector of Customs, Calcutta, confiscated 50 drums by order dated September 20, 1950.
The appellant imposed a personal penalty of Rs. 61,000 on the respondent under the Sea Customs Act, No. 8 of 1878.
The respondent appealed to the Central Board of Revenue under s. 188 of the Act, and this appeal was dismissed in April 1952.
The respondent filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Calcutta High Court.
Before a learned Single Judge, question raised as to jurisdiction of High Court in view of Election Commission India v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao.
Matter referred to larger bench and considered by Full Bench of Calcutta High Court.

Full Bench held no jurisdiction to issue writ against Central Board of Revenue (outside jurisdiction), but jurisdiction exists against Collector of Customs as operative order is his, since appeal merely dismissed.
Full Bench directed petition to be placed before Single Judge for disposal on merits.
Certificate granted by Calcutta High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court would have jurisdiction to issue a writ against the Collector of Customs Calcutta in spite of the fact that his order was taken in appeal to the Central Board of Revenue against which the High Court could not issue a writ and the appeal had been dismissed.

petitioner_arguments.text: The order of the original authority merges in the order of the appellate authority even where the appellate authority merely dismisses the appeal without modification.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principle of merger; precedents like A. Thangal Kunju Mudaliar v. M. Venkitachalam Potti; CIT v. Amritlal Bhogilal; Madan Gopal Rungta v. Secretary to Government of Orissa

respondent_arguments.text: High Court has jurisdiction over original authority within its territory even if appellate authority outside jurisdiction merely dismisses appeal.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rajasthan High Court in Barkatali v. Custodian General; State of Uttar Pradesh v. Mohammed Nooh

respondent_arguments.text: Distinction where appellate authority merely confirms without modification.

court_reasoning.text: When an appeal is made, appellate authority can reverse, modify, or confirm by dismissing appeal; in all cases, operative order is appellate order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellate order of confirmation is as efficacious as reversal or modification.

court_reasoning.text: Issuing writ to original authority would interfere with appellate order, which High Court lacks jurisdiction over.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principle that appellate order is operative after appeal disposed of.

court_reasoning.text: Approves PEPSU, Nagpur, Allahabad High Courts; disapproves Rajasthan initial view post-Thangal Kunju.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Merger applies even on mere dismissal.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes State of UP v. Mohammed Nooh as special case on pre-Constitution dismissal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mohammed Nooh stands on its own facts; merger principle repelled there for specific reasons.

holdings.text: Once order of original authority carried in appeal to appellate authority beyond High Court's jurisdiction, High Court cannot issue writ to original authority after appeal disposed of, even if merely confirmed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Election Commission India v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao
precedents_cited.relevance: Basis for no jurisdiction over Central Board of Revenue outside territory

precedents_cited.case_name: Barkatali v. Custodian General of Evacuee Property
precedents_cited.relevance: Held jurisdiction over original authority; later overruled by Rajasthan itself post-Thangal Kunju

precedents_cited.case_name: Joginder Singh Waryam Singh v. Director, Rural Rehabilitation, Pepsu Patiala
precedents_cited.relevance: No writ to original if appellate outside jurisdiction even on dismissal

precedents_cited.case_name: Burhanpur National Textile Workers Union v. Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Bombay
Azmat Ullah v. Custodian, Evacuee Property
A. Thangal Kunju Mudaliar v. M. Venkitachalam Potti
precedents_cited.relevance: Approved PEPSU, Nagpur, Allahabad views on merger

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Messrs. Amritlal Bhogilal and Company
precedents_cited.relevance: Appellate decision operative even on confirmation; original merges

precedents_cited.case_name: Madan Gopal Rungta v. Secretary to the Government of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Appellate order effective; distinguished Mohammed Nooh

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Mohammed Nooh
precedents_cited.relevance: Special facts of pre-Constitution dismissal; merger not applicable there

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court held that the Calcutta High Court lacks jurisdiction to issue a writ against the Collector of Customs once the appeal was dismissed by the Central Board of Revenue, which is beyond its territorial jurisdiction, due to the merger of the original order in the appellate order.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; High Court's jurisdiction decision overturned

key_quotes.text: "In law, the appellate order of confirmation is quite as efficacious as an operative order as an appellate order of reversal or modification."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on merger doctrine applying to confirmation

key_quotes.text: "There can be no doubt that, if an appeal is provided against an order passed by a tribunal, the decision of the appellate authority is the operative decision in law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quote from CIT v. Amritlal adopted to affirm merger principle

key_quotes.text: "Mohammad Nooh's case was a special case, which stands on its own facts."
key_quotes.speaker: court
